thread.title: Abortion foes to Congress: Use budget tactic to defund Planned Parenthood
thread.title_full: Abortion foes to Congress: Use budget tactic to defund Planned Parenthood | Washington Examiner

author: Paige Winfield Cunningham
title: Abortion foes to Congress: Use budget tactic to defund Planned Parenthood
text:
Several dozen anti-abortion groups wrote to Congress Monday, urging lawmakers to try to strip federal funds from Planned Parenthood by using a special legislative tactic.
The House is already moving in that direction, with the House Budget Committee planning a Friday hearing on what's known as a budget reconciliation bill, which can pass the Senate with a simple majority instead of the typical 60-vote threshold.
The bill says the women's health and abortion provider can't receive federal funds for one year and redirects the money to other health centers. It is Republicans' second try to defund Planned Parenthood, after an initial attempt to strip funding in a bill funding the government through the fall.
Thirty-five groups, including the Susan B. Anthony List, National Right to Life and the Family Research Council, are supporting the reconciliation effort, writing to Congress that "Planned Parenthood and other abortion businesses do not need or deserve taxpayer funding."
  Report: Obama to meet families of Oregon victims Last week after the shooting took place, the president repeated his call for gun control.
By Daniel Chaitin • 10/05/15 10:01 PM "Instead, these tax dollars would be put to better use at local community health centers, which provide all the same health services Planned Parenthood does (and usually more), but do not abort the lives of unborn children and callously harvest their body parts for profit," the groups wrote.
The reconciliation bill does not target other abortion providers.
The effort came about after a series of undercover videos in which abortion foe David Daleiden captured top Planned Parenthood officials discussing how some clinics provide aborted fetal tissue for medical research. The footage has prompted an outcry among Republicans against Planned Parenthood and has started several GOP-led investigations into the group.
The reconciliation bill defunding Planned Parenthood would likely get further than any other legislation vehicle, as it could pass the Senate. But President Obama is sure to veto it, and Republicans don't have enough votes in the Senate to override a veto.
Also from the Washington Examiner Reid: Republicans 'puppets' of the NRA The minority leader urged his colleagues Monday to pass legislation to require mandatory background checks.
By Daniel Chaitin • 10/05/15 9:14 PM
